[Question]
i m currently taking 0mg effexor xr for anxiety and depression i ve also taken lexapro 0mg for year and zoloft 00mg for a year both had similar effect barely put a dent in my anxiety and really helped with the severe symptom of depression but it s still there my anxiety is still bad particularly my physical symptom i always feel on edge and nervous i can always feel my heart pounding hard not fast regardless of my mental state and it s the most debilitating symptom i feel i can never relax and never truly enjoy myself because of how anxious i feel i take propranolol 0mg twice a day and is the only thing that help a little with the physical symptom but they re still problematic i have tried meditation breathing exercise exercise i have read a multitude of book on cognitive behavioral therapy acceptance and commitment therapy and mindfulness no exercise in the book ha helped with the symptom whatsoever i should also mention i have had test for my thyroid adrenal any gi or diet issue antibody etc and i m sure i can rule out physical cause is anyone else in a similar boat to me and found buspirone helped if no ha anything helped you thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've reached out for support regarding your anxiety and depression. It can be challenging when medications don't seem to have the desired effect, but there are still options available to explore.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that everyone's experience with mental health is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, buspirone has been found to be helpful for some individuals in managing anxiety symptoms. Buspirone is a medication commonly used to treat generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) and can help reduce feelings of nervousness and promote relaxation.

In terms of dosage, buspirone typically starts at a low dose and gradually increases over time. The starting dose is usually around 5 mg once or twice daily, and the maximum recommended dose is 60 mg per day. It's important to consult with a healthcare professional who can provide personalized guidance based on your specific needs and medical history.

In addition to medication options, it may also be beneficial to continue exploring other strategies that can complement your treatment. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is a widely recognized approach that focuses on identifying and changing negative thought patterns and behaviors associated with anxiety. While you mentioned not finding any exercises or techniques helpful thus far, it's worth noting that CBT is often delivered by trained therapists and involves regular sessions over an extended period. It may be worth discussing with a mental health professional if CBT could be a suitable option for you.

Other techniques that may be worth considering include deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, mindfulness meditation, and engaging in regular physical activity. These practices can help regulate the body's stress response and promote a sense of calmness.

Remember, finding the right combination of treatments and techniques that work for you may take time and experimentation. It's essential to have open and honest communication with your healthcare provider, who can guide you through this process and monitor your progress.

Please keep in mind that I am not a mental health professional, but I hope these suggestions can provide you with some guidance and options to discuss with a healthcare provider. Remember, seeking professional advice is crucial when it comes to your mental health, as they can offer personalized recommendations based on your specific needs and circumstances.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
so i started having suicidal thought in april of last year and they lasted until around november in october i started hanging out with a girl and we started becoming good friend not romantic just friendship my mental health started getting a lot better after a couple month of friendship with her and it s kept getting better ever since a few day ago i made a passive aggressive comment that really upset her she won t text me back now i ve tried apologizing and trying to make thing right with her but i haven t heard back from her i m afraid i ve ruined this friendship forever and now my suicidal thought are back for the first time since last year i always hurt the people that i care about and i hate myself so much that i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling distressed about your situation. It sounds like you've been through a lot, and it's important to acknowledge the impact of your past traumas on your mental health.

In regards to your suicidal thoughts, it's crucial to prioritize your safety. If you ever find yourself in immediate danger, please reach out to emergency services or a helpline right away. They can provide the necessary support and assistance you may need.

Regarding your friendship with the girl, it's common for relationships to have ups and downs. Communication is key during difficult times, so try expressing how sorry you are for upsetting her and explain your intentions behind the comment. Give her space to respond at her own pace without pressuring her. Remember, friendships require understanding and forgiveness from both parties.

It's important to recognize that self-hatred can often stem from internalized negative beliefs. Try practicing self-compassion by reminding yourself of your worth and focusing on your positive qualities. Consider engaging in activities that bring you joy and boost your self-esteem. Surrounding yourself with supportive individuals who appreciate and value you can also make a significant difference.

Additionally, exploring healthier coping mechanisms can be beneficial. Engaging in therapy or counseling can provide a safe space to process your emotions, gain insights into your behaviors, and develop effective strategies for managing difficult feelings. You might also find solace in creative outlets such as journaling, art, or exercise. These activities can help you express and release emotions in a healthy way.

Remember, healing takes time, and setbacks are part of the journey. Be patient with yourself and reach out for support when needed. You deserve to be loved and respected, just like anyone else.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

so i have a mild stutter and i just had an epiphany i ve been letting my stutter control me but i found something amazing out i let my stutter define who i wa a a person instead of an aspect of myself it s so bad that when my parent talk to me like a normal person i d think to myself wow they act like i m normal despite my stutter they see past that and when i would work people would see my name tag and say oh i have a son named my name and i would think he probably doesn t stutter tho i let this define who i wa a a person and i let it really get to me i wa looking at old reddit post from other people asking how people view stutter and most people said they didn t care at all and even found it interesting some even said it wa hot cute made joke sound more natural and a a result more funny not like they found the stutter funny tho and one even said they were turned on by it and someone said something that stuck out to me they pretty much said how you perceive yourself is how others will so if i see myself a weird and anxious i will act that way and be perceived in that way but if i see myself a confident and charismatic and just act like my stutter doesn t bother me and even joke about it then others will perceive me a such this blew my mind a i thought everyone didn t pick up on my stutter at first and just thought i wa super weird but it s just me convincing myself of that so even tho this clicked i still can t just flick the switch off so how do i actually become confident with my stutter it s very mild and is fueled by anxiety so if i can get rid of my anxiety it ll in my opinion make me sound more charismatic and confident so i really wan na figure out how to just own it how do i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've had this epiphany and are ready to take control of how your stutter affects you. It can be challenging, but with time and practice, you can definitely become more confident in owning your stutter.

Firstly, it's important to remember that building confidence takes time and patience. Start by acknowledging the progress you make, no matter how small it may seem. Celebrate each step forward and remind yourself of the strengths and qualities you possess beyond your stutter.

One helpful strategy is to work on reducing anxiety around your stutter. This can involve deep breathing exercises or other relaxation techniques before speaking situations. Additionally, try to challenge negative thoughts or beliefs you may have about yourself and replace them with more positive and realistic ones. Remind yourself that your stutter doesn't define who you are as a person.

In terms of speaking more confidently, practice is key. Start by gradually exposing yourself to situations where you can practice using your voice without fear of judgment. Consider joining a support group or seeking out opportunities to speak publicly in a supportive environment. As you gain more experience, you'll likely find it easier to navigate conversations and presentations with confidence.

Another important aspect is self-acceptance. Embrace your stutter as part of your unique identity. When you joke about it and own it in a light-hearted way, you're normalizing it for others and taking away its power over you. This can help alleviate some of the anxiety associated with speaking and open up opportunities for connection and understanding.

Lastly, don't hesitate to reach out to others who have experienced similar challenges. Connecting with individuals who have overcome their own insecurities around speech can provide valuable insights and encouragement. Online communities or local support groups can be great resources for finding mentors and friends who understand what you're going through.

Remember, this journey is unique to you, and there's no one-size-fits-all approach. Be patient with yourself and celebrate the progress you make along the way. With time and effort, you can develop the confidence to own your stutter and embrace all that you have to offer.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m terrible at articulating my thought so apology in advance let me just say up front that no plan ha been made and despite thinking about it so much i don t think i could go through with it this is just a vent piece i guess i feel like such a burden all the time i genuinely only have one real friend left and feel like my roommate co worker hate me i m anti social and awkward i don t make eye contact and i don t talk at all ever i take way too long to text back if i did km i honestly don t think anyone would know until a body wa found or over a month had passed i m just so sick of feeling like an obstacle all the time like i m always in the way or always wrong to think feel a certain way but all of this seems pretty normal i realise it s not a healthy mindset but literally everyone on earth ha trauma everyone ha their own shit they re going through and not only doe it seem like they re handling it a lot better than me but they have real problem i have friend who lost their job over the pandemic i have friend going through break ups grief or whatever and they still manage to practice their hobby and interact with their fellow man but then there s me doing literally fucking nothing all day every day after work and having the ball to feel like shit over it a if it s out of my control i feel weak willed lazy and most of all i feel like the world s biggist egomaniac for writing so much about myself a if it needed to be said thank you for reading my aimless rambling the thought were very intrusive tonight so i just needed to self depricate i guess good night everyone

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's completely understandable that you might feel like a burden and like you're always in the way or wrong. It can be challenging when you're dealing with intrusive thoughts, especially at night. Remember that these thoughts don't define who you are as a person.

One suggestion I have is to try practicing self-compassion. Instead of being hard on yourself for having intrusive thoughts, try to offer yourself understanding and kindness. Remind yourself that everyone has their own struggles and that it's okay to have difficult thoughts. You could also try engaging in activities that bring you joy or help you relax, such as listening to music, reading a book, or taking a walk outside. These activities may help distract your mind from the intrusive thoughts.

In terms of feeling like an obstacle, it might be helpful to challenge any negative beliefs you have about yourself. Ask yourself if there is evidence to support these beliefs or if they are based on assumptions. Try to focus on your strengths and accomplishments instead of dwelling on perceived shortcomings. It can also be beneficial to work on building your self-esteem by setting small achievable goals for yourself and celebrating your successes, no matter how small they may seem.

Regarding your feelings of loneliness and social anxiety, it might be helpful to gradually expose yourself to social situations that feel manageable for you. Start by reaching out to one or two trusted friends and arranging a low-pressure activity together, such as grabbing a coffee or going for a walk. With time and practice, you may find that your confidence grows, and you become more comfortable interacting with others.

Remember that therapy can be a valuable resource for addressing these challenges. A therapist can provide guidance, support, and practical strategies tailored to your specific needs. They can help you navigate intrusive thoughts, build self-esteem, and improve your overall well-being. If you're open to it, consider seeking out a therapist who specializes in cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), which has been shown to be effective in treating anxiety and depression.

Lastly, it's important to remember that change takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself as you work towards improving your mental health. Celebrate even the smallest victories along the way, and don't hesitate to reach out for support when you need it. You deserve to feel at peace within yourself and to find joy in life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

for context i m an english teacher at a small private english school the school is so small i m the only teacher no sub i got my period last night and a always the first day is the worst cramp headache nausea needing the loo every minute and i feel so freaking cold today no matter what i do i just can t seem to get warm so i cancelled my two afternoon lesson and asked the receptionist to deal with a meeting with a potential client herself i mean that s pretty much her job anyway but i feel so guilty for cancelling the class the nausea got worse a soon a i sent the text to my bos i feel bad that i have to cancel two class in one day especially since i had a week holiday the week before last maybe the student are losing too much lesson time this year my class today were from to 0 and then to but i don t go home in the gap between meaning i d have to sit at my desk with nothing comfy or warm for hour all while feeling really crappy idk just looking for someone to tell me it ok to take a sick day if i need it and tell the anxiety voice to shut the heck up edit thank you so much to everyone who commented and got me through the day i went to bed feeling better emotionally and physically than when i got up today is a new day

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Taking care of your physical and mental well-being is crucial, especially during challenging times. It's understandable that you're feeling unwell due to your period symptoms, and it's important to prioritize self-care.

Firstly, let's address the guilt you mentioned about cancelling classes. Remember that taking care of yourself is just as important as teaching. If you're not feeling well enough to teach effectively, it's completely valid to cancel your classes. Your job responsibilities include looking after your own health and well-being, which allows you to be more effective in your teaching overall.

Regarding the potential client meeting, delegating this task to the receptionist is a wise decision. They are there to assist with such matters, and it frees up your time to focus on your well-being. Additionally, keep in mind that their job involves handling various responsibilities, including client meetings, giving you more leeway to take care of yourself without feeling guilty.

When it comes to managing your period symptoms, there are several strategies you can try. One option is to use a heating pad or hot water bottle on your lower abdomen, which can help alleviate cramps. Taking over-the-counter painkillers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen may also reduce pain and inflammation. Peppermint tea or ginger supplements might help with nausea, and staying hydrated can be beneficial as well.

In terms of feeling cold despite trying different layers, it could be helpful to wear thermal underwear or long johns underneath your clothes. You can also consider using a shawl or scarf around your shoulders for added warmth. If you find yourself frequently needing to use the restroom, try emptying your bladder before starting your lesson and reminding students to give you short breaks if needed.

Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself during this time. Period symptoms can vary in intensity from day to day, so don't hesitate to take additional sick days if needed. Taking care of your physical health will ultimately contribute to improved teaching effectiveness and overall well-being.

Lastly, regarding your anxiety about cancelling classes, it's understandable that you may feel anxious about letting students down. However, it's essential to remind yourself that your health should always come first. Communicate openly with your students about the situation, emphasizing that taking care of yourself is necessary for their learning experience as well. You can reassure them that you'll make up for the missed content or provide alternative learning opportunities.

In conclusion, remember that prioritizing your well-being is crucial. Taking sick days when needed, delegating responsibilities, and implementing strategies to manage your period symptoms can help alleviate stress and discomfort. Communicate openly with your students about the situation, reassuring them that their learning will not be compromised. Take care of yourself, and know that it's okay to prioritize your health above all else.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

hi last year in matheletics i managed to bag at least top 0 but suddenly this year my playing condition have dropped because when i look at the leaderboard every time it make me more anxious and lead to bad performance in the competition now i can not even reach top 000 this ha been making me more stressed and now i even have mixed feeling to never take part in any of these competition even though it thing that i like are there any way to at least calm myself down

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling stressed and anxious about your recent performance in mathematics competitions. It can be disheartening when your playing condition suddenly drops after achieving good results last year. Let's explore some strategies to help you calm yourself down and work towards improving your performance:

1. Recognize and challenge negative thoughts: When you look at the leaderboard and feel anxious, try to identify any negative thoughts that may be influencing your emotions. Ask yourself if these thoughts are based on facts or if they are exaggerated assumptions. Challenge those negative thoughts by considering alternative perspectives or evidence that contradicts them.

2. Focus on process rather than outcome: Instead of solely focusing on the end result (such as your ranking), shift your attention to the process of learning and growing as a mathematician. Celebrate small achievements along the way, such as solving challenging problems or improving your understanding of mathematical concepts. my memory s fading i m losing weight i don t sleep sex feel hollow i have no motivation to do anything and i frequently think about death i ve been seeing these symptom in myself on and off again for the past few year but never really put them together until now i attributed the weight loss to a study i read stating that just thinking about working out can have benefit despite not actually working out i never really thought of it a a symptom i just saw it a a positive slightly inexplicable development in my life i think i read that i have passive intrusive thought or something like that essentially i think about what it would be like if i wa dead but not about how i would want to die or anything like that the reason for it wa always lost on me i just learned to live with it my sleep issue motivation issue and lack of sexual pleasure have always been present so i never really thought twice about them i thought the memory loss wa due to my rare and infrequent use of recreational psychedelics when i connected all of these together i spent about 0 minute just trying to remember what i had for dinner last night which i found fairly upsetting a up until my teenage year i had an immaculate memory i d still consider myself happy at least to the extent that i ve always known but the symptom are there nevertheless and i m just finding the whole thing quite strange

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's important to acknowledge the symptoms you've described and understand that they can indeed be concerning. However, it's also crucial to remember that everyone's experiences are unique, and what may seem normal for one person might not be for another.

In terms of your memory loss, it's not uncommon for individuals to experience some decline in memory as they age. While this can be frustrating, there are strategies you can employ to help improve your recall. One effective method is to regularly challenge your brain with activities such as puzzles, games, or even learning something new. Additionally, creating routines and organizing your environment can also assist in compensating for any memory lapses.

Regarding your weight loss, it's essential to consult with a healthcare professional who can evaluate your specific situation. They can determine if there are any underlying medical conditions contributing to this symptom. In the meantime, paying attention to your nutrition and ensuring you're getting proper nourishment is important. Engaging in regular physical activity, even if it's not exercising per se, can still have benefits for your overall well-being.

Sleep disturbances can significantly impact our mental and physical health. Establishing a consistent sleep routine, creating a relaxing bedtime ritual, and ensuring your sleep environment is conducive to restful sleep can all contribute to better sleep quality. If these measures don't improve your sleep, it may be beneficial to consult with a sleep specialist who can provide further guidance tailored to your specific needs.

Lack of sexual pleasure can be multifaceted and may require exploration by a healthcare provider. It's important to remember that sexuality is complex and can be influenced by various factors such as relationships, emotional well-being, and physical health. Communicating openly with your partner about your feelings and seeking support from a sex therapist or counselor might be helpful in understanding and addressing this symptom.

Feelings of emptiness and lack of motivation can be challenging to navigate, but it's important to remember that you're not alone in experiencing them. Engaging in activities that bring you joy, connecting with loved ones, and finding meaning in your daily life can help combat these feelings. Exploring hobbies, setting achievable goals, and practicing self-care are all potential avenues to explore.

Lastly, thoughts about death are not uncommon and can vary in intensity from person to person. It's essential to remind yourself that these thoughts do not necessarily indicate a mental health issue. However, if they become overwhelming or start to interfere with your daily functioning, it may be beneficial to seek support from a mental health professional who can provide guidance tailored to your specific situation.

Remember, everyone's experiences are unique, and what may seem concerning for one person might not be for another. It's important to consult with a healthcare professional who can provide an accurate assessment of your symptoms and offer appropriate guidance.

[Question]
i m starting a new job tomorrow and i m extremely anxious about it i m excited to start this new chapter but i just wish i didn t feel so nauseous right now i ve come really far in overcoming my anxiety but i ve taken everything slowly one baby step at a time this is a huge step the only job i ve had in the past year is instacarting grocery shop amp delivery that i started month ago i did everything at my own pace day a week and maybe a few order a day this job i m starting is hour shift time a week i shouldn t have set myself up for so much but i need to start working towards my career a a dog groomer and this bathing job is an incredible opportunity to do so my living situation is changing soon in that i will need to bring money to the table so i didn t have much of a choice the worst part is i can t actually bathe any dog until i ve learned from the other groomer how to do it which will take time so i worry that the day will go by really slowly because i won t even be doing anything or getting paid until i am ready to start bathing which i don t know how long that will take a friend of mine who work there in the pet store not in the grooming room pulled a lot of string for me with the bos a well my entire family and boyfriend family know i m starting tomorrow and are so happy to see me finally starting to do something meaningful they ve all had a problem with my not working for year because of my anxiety i just feel like not only for my sake but for everyone else s sake i can not screw this up i feel like i m throwing myself into the deep end and hoping i can swim

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Starting a new job can definitely be nerve-wracking, and it's completely normal to feel anxious about it. It's great that you're excited to start this new chapter in your life, but I understand how the nerves can make you feel nauseous.

Taking small steps towards overcoming anxiety is a fantastic approach, and it's wonderful that you've come so far. This new job might feel like a big step for you, but remember that everyone starts somewhere. You've already shown resilience and determination by gradually increasing your Instacart orders.

It's understandable that this job may require more structure and consistency than what you're used to, but try not to put too much pressure on yourself. Take it one day at a time and remind yourself that it's okay to make mistakes or feel overwhelmed initially. Remember, learning new skills takes time, and you'll gradually become more comfortable as you go along.

Regarding bathing dogs without getting paid right away, keep in mind that it's common for employees to undergo training before starting certain tasks. Use this time to observe and learn from the other groomer. By doing so, you'll gain valuable knowledge and experience that will ultimately benefit both you and the dogs you'll be grooming in the future.

Your family and boyfriend's support is truly heartwarming. While it's natural to want to prove yourself and succeed, remember that nobody is perfect. Mistakes happen, and that's part of the learning process. Trust in your abilities and know that setbacks are often opportunities for growth.

To manage your anxiety during the first few days at your new job, here are some suggestions:

1. Prepare ahead of time: Research the company, familiarize yourself with their values and mission, and review any materials they may have provided. This will help boost your confidence and make you feel more prepared on your first day.

2. Practice self-care: Make sure to prioritize your physical and mental well-being. Get enough sleep, eat nutritious meals, exercise regularly, and engage in activities that help you relax and unwind. Taking care of yourself will give you the energy and resilience needed to navigate any challenges that may arise.

3. Set realistic expectations: Understand that it's normal to feel anxious and make mistakes during your first few days. Remind yourself that everyone has a learning curve and that it's okay to ask questions or seek guidance when needed.

4. Take breaks when needed: If you find yourself feeling overwhelmed or anxious, don't hesitate to take short breaks throughout the day. Use this time to breathe deeply, stretch, or engage in activities that help you relax. Taking breaks can provide much-needed relief and allow you to return to work with a clearer mind.

5. Celebrate small victories: Recognize and celebrate your achievements, no matter how small they may seem. Each step forward is significant, and acknowledging your progress can boost your confidence and motivation.

Remember, starting a new job can be challenging, but it's also an opportunity for growth and personal development. Trust in your abilities, take it one day at a time, and remember that setbacks are only temporary obstacles on the path to success. Good luck with your new job, and I'm confident that you'll do great!
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i feel like wanting to die why do i not have friend i feel soo empty lonely i mean i do have a lot of people i talk to on a daily basis but for some reason i feel the need to always have someone almost all the time with me like if i stay alone for hour i feel lonely it is weird i just wish to be happy i don t want to kill myself

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling lonely and empty without a friend by your side. Having someone to talk to and spend time with can bring a sense of fulfillment and happiness. While I'm not an expert, I can offer some suggestions that might help in finding companionship:

1. Consider joining social or hobby-based groups: Look for activities or clubs that align with your interests. This could provide opportunities to meet like-minded individuals who share similar passions.

2. Volunteer or engage in community service: By volunteering, you can not only give back to the community but also connect with others who have similar values. It's a great way to build relationships while making a positive impact.

3. Attend local events or gatherings: Keep an eye out for events happening in your area. These could include festivals, workshops, or even meetups organized by organizations or groups. Engaging in these events may lead to meaningful connections.

4. Take up a new hobby or interest: Pursuing a hobby or interest can open doors to new social circles. Whether it's joining a sports team, taking a class, or attending a book club, sharing your passion with others can create bonds.

5. Utilize online platforms: There are various online communities and forums where you can connect with people who share common experiences or interests. However, remember to prioritize your safety and well-being by being cautious about the information you share online.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone in feeling this way. It's completely understandable that living at home with your parents would be challenging for you, especially if you're trying to navigate your own mental health struggles.

Firstly, it's important to prioritize your own well-being. While I understand that it may feel difficult to set boundaries with your parents, it's crucial for your mental health to have some alone time. You could try having an open and honest conversation with them about how important it is for you to have some quiet time each day. Maybe you can come up with a signal or a specific time that lets them know when you need space.

In addition to setting boundaries, finding ways to manage stress and depression can greatly improve your overall well-being. One technique that might be helpful is deep breathing exercises. When you start feeling overwhelmed or anxious, taking slow, deep breaths can help calm your nervous system. You can also try incorporating relaxation techniques into your daily routine, such as meditation or mindfulness exercises.

Another strategy that may be beneficial is reaching out for support from friends, family, or even online communities. Connecting with others who understand what you're going through can provide a sense of validation and comfort. Additionally, consider seeking professional help if you haven't already. A therapist or counselor can offer guidance tailored specifically to your situation and provide you with additional coping strategies.

Lastly, it's important to remember that healing takes time. Be patient and kind to yourself as you navigate through this difficult period. Celebrate small victories and try to focus on activities that bring you joy, even if they don't seem as fun as they used to be at first.

Remember, you are deserving of happiness and peace in your life. Keep reaching out for support and exploring different coping strategies until you find what works best for you. You're stronger than you realize, and with time and support, things can get better.

In terms of memory loss, it's not uncommon for depression to impact cognitive functioning temporarily. i m not the same person and i didn t like the person i wa before that so it s not even considered a loss but now i just stopped caring i genuinely stopped caring and it make me want to hate myself but the thing is im too exhausted to even hate myself i just feel like nothing just an empty space where a human used to be i ve stopped caring and it scare me i know the final step is when you stop caring and im at this step i don t care to pursue my passion or talent because whats the point why live a live when i will be forgotten why wa i even made like why even bother trying what even is the point in living if i can t be bothered to try

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling like you're not the same person and that you don't like the person you were before. It can be difficult when our feelings change and we lose interest in things we once enjoyed. However, it's important to remember that change is a normal part of life, and it doesn't necessarily mean that you've lost something valuable.

When it comes to hobbies and interests, it's common for our tastes to evolve over time. What used to bring us joy may no longer resonate with us, and that's okay. It doesn't mean that those experiences were worthless or that we've lost out on anything. It simply means that we're growing and discovering new things that bring us fulfillment.

In terms of pursuing your passion or talent, it's natural to feel unmotivated at times. Creativity can ebb and flow, and sometimes we need to take a step back and recharge. It doesn't mean that you should give up on your dreams entirely. Instead, consider exploring different aspects of your passion or taking a break to focus on other areas of your life. You might find that inspiration strikes again when you least expect it.

As for the question of why we're alive, it's a deeply personal and complex topic. Each individual has their own unique purpose and meaning in life. For some, it may be about helping others, while for others, it could be about creating art or experiencing joy. It's important to remind yourself that your life has value simply because you exist. You don't need a specific goal or achievement to justify your being here.

Remember, these feelings of not caring can be overwhelming, but they don't define who you are as a person. Take the time to explore new interests, reconnect with loved ones, and prioritize self-care. If you find that these feelings persist or become too much to handle on your own, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and stuck in your current situation. It can be challenging when you feel like you're not enjoying life and don't have a sense of purpose. However, there are steps you can take to improve your well-being and find some direction.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that giving up on yourself is not the answer. While it may seem like an escape, it will only lead to a cycle of self-destruction. Instead, try to focus on small goals or activities that bring you joy or a sense of accomplishment. This could include hobbies, creative outlets, or even setting aside time each day for self-care.

In terms of your eating habits, it might be helpful to establish a routine that includes regular, balanced meals. You can start by setting specific meal times and trying to incorporate nutritious foods into your diet. It's also important to remember that progress takes time, so be patient with yourself as you work towards healthier habits.

Exercise can play a significant role in improving your mood and overall well-being. Start with small, achievable goals such as taking short walks outside or finding enjoyable physical activities that you can do at home. Gradually increase the duration and intensity of your workouts as you feel more comfortable.

Regarding your eczema, consider exploring different skincare routines or seeking advice from a dermatologist. They can provide guidance on managing your symptoms and finding products that work best for you. Remember, taking care of your skin doesn't have to be overwhelming; start with simple steps like moisturizing regularly and avoiding harsh soaps or detergents.

It's common for people to use substances or activities as a way to numb their emotions. However, finding healthier coping mechanisms is crucial for your well-being. Explore alternative ways to manage stress and emotions, such as talking to a trusted friend, journaling, practicing mindfulness or meditation, or engaging in hobbies that bring you joy.

Lastly, it's important to address the thoughts of self-harm and suicide. If you ever find yourself in a crisis or feeling unable to keep yourself safe, please reach out to a helpline or emergency services right away. There are people who genuinely care about your well-being and want to support you through this difficult time.

Remember, change takes time and effort, but it is possible to break free from the cycle of self-destruction. Focus on small steps towards self-care, reaching out for support when needed, and exploring healthier ways to cope with your emotions. You deserve to live a fulfilling life, even if it may not look like what you had imagined.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be incredibly frustrating and disheartening when good things in our lives seem to disappear unexpectedly, especially when we've worked hard for them or they hold significant value to us. It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and struggling to cope with these experiences.

In situations like this, it can be helpful to take a step back and try to gain some perspective. While it may feel like a pattern of things disappearing without explanation, it's important to remember that life is full of uncertainties and changes beyond our control. Sometimes, it can be beneficial to focus on the things that are within our control and work towards finding solutions or alternatives.

When faced with multiple challenges, it's natural to feel emotionally drained and want to vent or seek support from others. However, as you've experienced, reaching out for help can sometimes lead to disappointment or feeling invalidated. This can add an additional layer of frustration and make it even more challenging to navigate your emotions.

During times like these, it might be helpful to explore alternative ways to process your feelings and find support. Journaling, engaging in creative outlets, or talking with trusted friends or family members who are understanding and empathetic can provide some relief. Additionally, seeking out online communities or forums where individuals share similar experiences may offer a sense of validation and support.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to give yourself permission to explore different coping strategies and find what resonates with you personally. Taking small steps towards self-care and prioritizing your emotional well-being can make a significant difference in managing overwhelming emotions.

Lastly, if you ever find yourself in a crisis or experiencing thoughts of self-harm, please know that there are resources available to support you. Consider reaching out to helplines specifically dedicated to mental health crises, such as crisis hotlines or text services. They can provide a listening ear, offer guidance, and connect you with the appropriate support systems.

Take care of yourself and remember that you're not alone in this journey.

Consider incorporating activities such as reading a book, taking a warm bath, or practicing deep breathing exercises before bed. Additionally, creating a comfortable sleep environment by ensuring your bedroom is dark, quiet, and at a cool temperature can also contribute to better sleep quality.

If you find yourself lying awake in bed counting down the hours until work, it might be beneficial to try some relaxation techniques to help calm your mind. Deep breathing exercises, meditation, or listening to soothing music can all help reduce anxiety and promote relaxation. You could also consider keeping a journal next to your bed where you can write down any racing thoughts or worries that may be keeping you up. This can provide a sense of release, allowing you to let go of those thoughts temporarily and give yourself permission to sleep.

While it's completely normal to feel lonely during challenging times, it's important to remember that you don't have to go through this alone. Consider reaching out to friends, family members, or even online communities who may understand what you're going through. Sharing your feelings with others who can offer support and empathy can provide immense relief and help alleviate some of the emotional burden you're carrying.

Remember, seeking professional help from a therapist or counselor can also be incredibly beneficial. They can provide guidance tailored specifically to your needs and help you navigate through these difficult emotions. If you feel comfortable doing so, I encourage you to consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can offer you the support and guidance you deserve.

Take care of yourself and prioritize self-care as much as possible. Remember that it's okay to ask for help when you need it. You are not alone in this journey, and there are resources available to support you.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been through a lot and I can understand how frustrating and overwhelming it must be for you. It's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to help improve your situation.

Firstly, it's great that you're seeking support and guidance during this difficult time. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some suggestions that may be helpful for you.

1. Communication: Open and honest communication with your mother is key. Try expressing your feelings calmly and assertively, explaining how certain aspects of her suggestions are impacting you negatively. Share your perspective while also being respectful of hers. This might help her better understand your point of view and potentially lead to compromises that work better for both of you.

2. Boundaries: Establishing clear boundaries within your living arrangement can be crucial for maintaining your mental well-being. Discuss with your mother what you consider to be reasonable boundaries, such as having dedicated quiet time for yourself or setting specific times when you don't want to be disturbed. Having these boundaries in place can give you a sense of autonomy and reduce conflicts.

3. Support system: Building a strong support system outside of your immediate family can be incredibly beneficial. Consider reaching out to friends, joining social groups, or exploring hobbies that align with your interests. Having people who understand and support you can provide a valuable source of emotional support and companionship.

4. Self-care: Taking care of yourself is essential during challenging times. Make sure to prioritize activities that bring you joy and relaxation, whether it's engaging in hobbies, practicing mindfulness exercises, or simply taking breaks when needed. Remember that self-care looks different for everyone, so find what works best for you.

5. Professional growth: While it may feel discouraging at times, there are resources available to help you navigate your job search and enhance your skills. Consider researching career development workshops, networking events, or online courses that could potentially improve your chances of finding a better job. Additionally, seeking guidance from a career counselor or employment agency might provide valuable insights tailored to your specific situation.

6. Seeking professional help: If you find that your feelings of depression and suicidal thoughts persist or worsen, it may be beneficial to consider reaching out to a mental health professional. They can provide you with the necessary support and guidance to navigate through this difficult period.

Remember, change takes time and effort, so be patient with yourself as you work towards finding a solution that works best for you. You deserve to live a fulfilling life with autonomy and happiness.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Taking a pill to help you sleep is a common coping mechanism, but it's also important to take care of yourself in other ways. One thing you could try is setting aside some time each day for self-care activities that bring you joy or relaxation. This might include things like taking a warm bath, reading a book, listening to music, or practicing mindfulness exercises.

In addition to self-care, reaching out to others for support can make a big difference. You mentioned wanting to wake up to zero notifications, which suggests that social media or messaging apps have been weighing heavily on your mind. Consider turning off notifications temporarily or even taking a break from these platforms altogether. It may feel strange at first, but giving yourself the space to disconnect can be incredibly beneficial for your mental well-being.

Instead of relying solely on digital connections, consider reaching out to friends or loved ones in person. Plan a coffee date, go for a walk together, or simply have a heartfelt conversation. Connecting with others face-to-face can provide a sense of genuine support and help alleviate feelings of loneliness.

Lastly, if you find yourself struggling with overwhelming sadness or thoughts of self-harm, please reach out to a helpline or crisis hotline in your area. They are trained professionals who are there to listen and offer guidance during difficult times. Remember, you are not alone, and there are resources available to support you.

[Question]
hi all i m f i ve had very bad anxiety disorder since 0 0 when my uncle passed away the following year i started taking medication and while it help it s not a cure all both my parent passed under different circumstance in october and it s wrecked my emotion i try to do the best i can but sometimes it s just a mess i m out of town right now and i feel so outside of my comfort zone i know i m safe but my stomach is in knot and sorry tmi i haven t left the bathroom much doe anyone have any advice is there anything i can do to calm myself or center myself thank you in advance

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be incredibly challenging to navigate anxiety, especially when it's triggered by significant life events like the losses you've experienced. It's understandable that your emotions are running high right now.

One strategy that may help is deep breathing exercises. When you notice your anxiety escalating, take a moment to focus on your breath. Inhale deeply through your nose, hold for a few seconds, and then exhale slowly through your mouth. This simple technique can help activate your body's relaxation response and bring a sense of calmness.

Another helpful practice is grounding techniques. These involve bringing your attention to the present moment and connecting with your senses. For example, you can try focusing on the physical sensations of your feet touching the ground or noticing the colors and shapes around you. Engaging your senses can redirect your thoughts away from anxious patterns and provide a sense of stability.

Journaling can also be beneficial. Writing down your feelings and experiences allows you to express yourself freely and gain insight into your emotions. You mentioned that you've been out of town, which can sometimes create unfamiliar situations. By jotting down your thoughts and reflections, you can process any challenges you encounter and develop a better understanding of yourself.

Additionally, finding healthy outlets for your emotions can make a difference. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as listening to music, practicing mindfulness or meditation, or going for walks in nature, can help alleviate anxiety symptoms. Experiment with different activities and find what works best for you.

Remember, everyone's journey with anxiety is unique, so it might take time to discover the coping strategies that resonate most with you. If you find that your anxiety continues to significantly impact your daily life, it could be beneficial to seek support from a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and assistance.

Take care of yourself and remember that you have the strength to navigate through this difficult time.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i fell pain on my left chest and on my left back when i looking for an answer on google i feel it s a symptom of heart disease my mother also ha this and a far a i know heart disease can be inherited i didn t dare to go to the doctor because in our family there is a saying that say it s better not to know

While I'm not a medical professional, it's important to remember that symptoms alone cannot determine whether or not you have a specific condition like heart disease. Firstly, it might be helpful to gather more information about your symptoms. Consider keeping track of when the pain occurs, its duration, intensity, and any other associated symptoms. This detailed record can provide valuable insights when discussing your concerns with a healthcare provider.

When it comes to seeking medical advice, it's essential to consult with a qualified professional who can properly evaluate your situation. They will take into account your symptoms, medical history, and family history to provide an accurate diagnosis. Remember, everyone's experience is unique, and what may be true for one person may not necessarily apply to another.

In regards to your family saying "it's better not to know," it's important to recognize that avoiding diagnosis can hinder proper treatment and management of potential health issues. By seeking professional guidance, you'll gain a better understanding of your own health status and be empowered to make informed decisions about your care.

To alleviate any anxiety you may be experiencing while waiting for an appointment with a healthcare provider, consider implementing self-care strategies into your routine. Engaging in activities that promote relaxation, such as deep breathing exercises, meditation, or gentle physical activity, can help reduce stress levels. Additionally, maintaining a balanced diet, getting enough sleep, and connecting with supportive friends or loved ones can contribute to your overall well-being.

Remember, I'm here to support you through this process. If you have any further questions or need assistance navigating your emotions, please don't hesitate to reach out.

 It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and stuck in your current situation. It can be challenging to navigate through life when you feel like you're not living up to expectations or experiencing a lack of fulfillment.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that comparing yourself with others can often lead to feelings of inadequacy. Remember that everyone's journey is unique, and success looks different for each person. Instead of focusing on what you haven't achieved, try setting goals that align with your values and interests. This can help shift your perspective towards personal growth and give you a sense of direction.

Regarding your trauma and self-hatred, it's crucial to address these issues with care and support. In terms of motivation and energy levels, it might be helpful to explore strategies that promote self-care and productivity. While medication could potentially be beneficial, it's essential to consult with a healthcare professional who can assess your specific situation and provide appropriate recommendations. They can evaluate if medication may be helpful in managing your mood swings, attitude, or anger. Remember, though, that medication alone may not solve all the challenges you're facing, and it's important to address underlying issues through therapy as well.

Lastly, consider exploring activities or hobbies that bring you joy and fulfillment. Engaging in things you enjoy can help break the cycle of monotony and provide a sense of purpose. Whether it's art, music, sports, volunteering, or anything else that sparks your interest, investing time in activities that align with your values can make a significant difference in your overall well-being.

A therapist can provide a safe space for you to process your experiences, learn coping strategies, and work towards healing. They can also help you develop resilience and build confidence in navigating challenging situations.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient with yourself throughout this process. You've already shown great resilience by reaching out and seeking support. Keep taking small steps towards self-care and remember that you deserve to feel safe and secure.

i don t feel like myself anymore and i don t think i can be fixed not a day go by where i wish i didn t wake up again i don t know what s wrong and i ve been trying so hard to be better i just can t do it anymore i m so sorry

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling like you're not yourself anymore and it can be really challenging to go through that. It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique and there isn't a one-size-fits-all solution. However, there are some steps you can take to help yourself during this difficult time.

Firstly, try to be patient with yourself. Healing takes time and it's okay to have ups and downs along the way. Give yourself permission to feel what you're feeling without judgment. Allow yourself to grieve for the person you used to be and the life you once had.

Additionally, consider reaching out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, and sharing how you're feeling. Sometimes talking about our emotions can provide relief and help us gain perspective. If you don't feel comfortable discussing it with someone close to you, you may want to explore other options like joining a support group or seeking guidance from an online community where you can connect with others who may have had similar experiences.

In terms of trying to "fix" yourself, it might be helpful to shift your focus away from fixing and more towards self-care. Take small steps to prioritize your well-being. This could include engaging in activities that bring you joy, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or meditation, getting enough sleep, eating nourishing meals, and incorporating exercise into your routine if you feel up to it.

Remember, progress may not happen overnight, but every little step counts. Celebrate your achievements, no matter how small they may seem. And if you find yourself struggling to motivate yourself, try setting realistic goals for yourself each day. Break down larger tasks into smaller, more manageable ones, and reward yourself when you accomplish them.

Lastly, please know that you are not alone in this journey. There are many people who have felt similar feelings of not being themselves and have found their way back to a place of happiness and fulfillment. Keep reminding yourself that you deserve happiness and continue to seek support from those around you.

Take care of yourself and remember to be kind to yourself during this process.

im and mo postpartum i don t know if i have ppocd but the intrusive thought are becoming unbearable my baby is healthy and for the most part happy a lot of the time i feel like a shitty mom because i work full time while my boyfriend is at home with the baby and when i get home im too exhausted to clean house or play with my baby i carry so much guilt about other people watching my son on my day off so i can get thing done because i m his mom and i should be able to take care of him and everything else myself tonight he wa losing his sh t bc he wa overtired his screaming made me feel like i wanted to hurt him or myself i would never hurt him but the thought get so loud i can t seem to escape them i wa in a psych hospital last month but it didn t help at all these thought are a constant sometimes i feel like having a baby wa the wrong choice and i ruined my life and the only way to fix my issue is to end it i just feel so alone

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone. Dealing with intrusive thoughts can be incredibly challenging, especially when they revolve around your role as a mother. It's important to remember that many women experience these kinds of thoughts after having a baby, and it doesn't mean you're a bad mom or that something is wrong with you.

Firstly, it's crucial to acknowledge the guilt and pressure you feel about not being able to do everything yourself. Remember that balancing work and parenting is difficult, and it's completely normal to need support from your partner or other family members. Try to give yourself permission to rest and recharge after work, knowing that asking for help is a sign of strength rather than weakness.

Regarding the intrusive thoughts about harming your child, it's essential to address them seriously but also remember that they are just thoughts and not reflective of your true feelings or actions. One helpful strategy is to challenge these thoughts by reminding yourself of all the positive and loving interactions you have with your child. Focus on the moments when you both connect and thrive together.

In terms of treatment options, it may be beneficial to reach out to a mental health professional who specializes in postpartum issues. They can provide guidance tailored specifically to your situation and help you develop coping strategies to manage the intensity of these thoughts. Additionally, consider discussing potential therapy options with your healthcare provider or pediatrician, as they may have resources available to support you.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to ask for help along the way. Reach out to friends, family, or support groups who may understand what you're going through. Sharing your experiences with others who have had similar thoughts can provide validation and reassurance.

Lastly, take care of yourself by practicing self-compassion. Be kind to yourself and try to engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. This could include hobbies, exercise, spending time with loved ones, or simply taking a few moments for yourself each day.

You are not alone in this journey, and there is hope for healing and growth. It's important to remember that seeking support is a sign of strength, not weakness. Keep reaching out and advocating for yourself, because you deserve to feel supported and find peace amidst the challenges you're facing.

It's important to remember that healing takes time and there is no rush to find all the answers at once. Taking small steps towards recovery, setting realistic goals for yourself, and celebrating even the smallest victories along the way can make a big difference. Remember to be gentle with yourself and practice self-compassion. You deserve kindness and patience as you navigate this journey.

dutifully working a job that doesn t care about my humanity training people to replace me dutifully caring for a pet that make my mental health worse training them a i stress cry dutifully filling out tax for my dead parent emailing lawyer because my sibling won t fulfill their legal obligation dutifully attending counseling with my spouse actively listening to being told my want and need are wrong dutifully laying in bed quietly so a not do disturb anyone else staring at the ceiling through insomnia and intrusive thought understanding that i don t exist i am just a tool for everyone else this is my duty

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of stress and feeling overwhelmed with the various responsibilities and duties you have in your life. It can be challenging to constantly prioritize others' needs and well-being while neglecting your own.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that you are not just a tool for everyone else. You are a unique individual with your own wants, needs, and emotions. It's crucial to remember that taking care of yourself is equally important as fulfilling your duties towards others.

To address the situation with your job, if you feel undervalued or unappreciated, it might be helpful to explore opportunities where you can find a work environment that aligns with your expectations and values. Consider identifying your strengths and skills, and look for roles that appreciate and utilize them.

Regarding your pet, if it negatively impacts your mental health, consider evaluating if the relationship is beneficial overall. If possible, you could try training it in a way that promotes positive reinforcement and reduces stress for both you and the pet. Additionally, incorporating self-care activities into your routine, such as engaging in hobbies or spending time with supportive friends, may help alleviate some of the mental strain.

For tax matters related to your dead parent, seeking guidance from an accountant or financial advisor might provide clarity and ease the burden. They can assist you in navigating the legal obligations and ensure everything is handled accurately.

Concerning your sibling and the counseling sessions with your spouse, assertiveness techniques might be beneficial. Clearly expressing your thoughts and feelings in a respectful manner can help communicate your needs effectively. You deserve to have your wants and needs acknowledged, so try exploring strategies like using "I" statements, setting boundaries, and practicing active listening yourself.

In terms of insomnia and intrusive thoughts, establishing a bedtime routine and creating a calming environment can promote better sleep. Engaging in relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, meditation, or journaling before bed may also help quiet your mind. If these strategies don't bring relief, consider consulting with a healthcare professional who can provide further guidance tailored to your specific situation.

Remember, finding a balance between fulfilling your duties and taking care of yourself is crucial for your overall well-being. It's important to prioritize self-care, set boundaries, and advocate for your own needs. You deserve to be recognized and valued as an individual, not solely seen as a tool for others.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

sorry if this is the wrong subreddit for a long time in my life all i wanted wa to have someone to be there for me a person that could love me back a much i love them back but now that i have it i don t know if it s what i wanted in my past i had suicidal friend that influenced a huge part of my life i begin to realize how stupid living wa and started to question why we live i m losing all my energy slowly and slowly i find myself losing all motivation and having no goal or dream anymore this reddit is my last ditch effort on seeking help from other people i ve already started to distance from everyone around me i know that i can t be the only one that s been or going through this how were you guy able to keep your energy and have a positive outlook on life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's completely understandable that you're feeling this way, and it's great that you've reached out for support. Having someone to love and be loved by is a wonderful thing, but it can also bring up questions and uncertainties about what we want in life.

Firstly, I want to assure you that you're not alone in experiencing these feelings. Many people go through similar struggles and question the purpose of life from time to time. It's natural to reevaluate our goals and dreams as we navigate different stages of life.

To keep your energy and maintain a positive outlook on life, there are a few things you can try. Firstly, consider exploring new hobbies or activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. Engaging in things you enjoy can help reignite your motivation and give you a sense of purpose.

Additionally, surrounding yourself with supportive and understanding individuals can make a significant difference. While it may feel challenging to connect with others right now, taking small steps towards building connections can be helpful. This could involve reaching out to friends or family members, joining social groups or communities centered around shared interests, or even seeking professional guidance if needed.

Another important aspect is self-care. Taking care of yourself physically, mentally, and emotionally is crucial. Make sure you're getting enough rest, eating well, and engaging in activities that promote relaxation and well-being. This might include practicing mindfulness or meditation, exercising regularly, or finding ways to destress that work for you.

Lastly, remember that it's okay to ask for help when needed. Seeking support from professionals or trusted individuals can provide valuable insights and guidance tailored to your specific situation. They can offer strategies to cope with negative thoughts and help you develop a more positive outlook on life.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. Be patient with yourself as you navigate these challenges, and know that there is hope for finding joy and meaning in life again.

the other hand i have been reading some post on here about how much med helped people i am hoping to hear from some people that have been on any of these medication and what their experience were also  It's great that you've taken the step to seek therapy for your anxiety, and I understand your concerns about medication. It's completely normal to have reservations about starting any new treatment, including medication.

When it comes to anxiety medication, it's important to remember that it's a tool that can be used in conjunction with therapy to help manage symptoms. Many people find that combining therapy with medication provides them with the support they need to effectively address their anxiety. However, it's also important to note that medication is not the only option for managing anxiety. Therapy alone can be very effective as well.

In terms of side effects, everyone's experience with medication can vary. Some people may experience mild side effects that go away over time, while others may not experience any side effects at all. It's important to discuss any concerns you have about side effects with your prescriber so they can provide you with information specific to the medication they are recommending for you.

If you're unsure about starting medication right away, it's completely understandable. You might consider discussing this with your therapist during your first session and coming up with a plan together. They can help you explore other coping strategies or techniques that may be helpful in managing your anxiety without medication. Remember, therapy is a collaborative process, and your therapist is there to support you in making decisions that are best for you.

It's also worth mentioning that even if you decide to start on medication, it doesn't necessarily mean you'll be on it forever. Many people find that they only need medication for a certain period of time, such as until their symptoms are more manageable, and then they can taper off the medication. It's important to have open communication with your prescriber about your goals and expectations for medication so they can work with you to find the best plan for your individual needs.

Lastly, remember that seeking support is a courageous step towards taking care of yourself. It's okay to have questions and uncertainties along the way, but know that you are not alone in this journey. Reach out to friends, family, or support groups who can offer encouragement and understanding as you navigate through therapy and potential medication.

I hope this information helps you gain some clarity on your options. Remember, it's important to trust your instincts and make decisions that feel right for you. If you have any additional questions or need further guidance, feel free to reach out.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

2. Challenge negative thoughts: When negative thoughts arise, try to challenge them by asking yourself if they are based on evidence or if they are simply assumptions. Remind yourself of instances where you have felt accepted by others or have successfully engaged in conversations.

 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone in feeling this way. It can be incredibly challenging to navigate daily life when dealing with depression, and it's completely understandable that it takes a toll on you.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge the effort you put in every day just to get by. Depression can make even the simplest tasks feel overwhelming, so please give yourself credit for any progress you make, no matter how small. You deserve recognition for your strength and resilience.

When it comes to eating dinner, it might be helpful to try breaking down the task into smaller steps. Start by setting aside specific times during the day to eat, whether it's breakfast, lunch, or an afternoon snack. Gradually work your way up to incorporating dinner back into your routine. [The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a specific type of anxiety that occurs when certain topics are discussed, particularly those related to personal preferences or sensitive subjects. This can be challenging and cause discomfort for you, but there are strategies you can try to help manage these situations.

Firstly, it may be helpful to recognize that everyone has their own opinions and preferences, and it's okay if they differ from yours. Remember that your worth isn't determined by other people's opinions or by agreeing with them all the time. Remind yourself that you have valid views and values, and trust in your own judgment.

In situations where conversations veer towards sensitive topics, you can practice assertiveness skills to navigate them more comfortably. One approach is to redirect the conversation back to a less triggering subject. For example, if the discussion turns to corrupt officers, you could change the focus by bringing up another work-related topic or asking a question about something unrelated.

Additionally, developing mindfulness techniques can assist in managing anxiety symptoms. When you feel yourself becoming overwhelmed or anxious during these conversations, take a moment to pause and focus on your breath. Allow yourself to observe and accept your thoughts and feelings without judgment. This practice can help ground you in the present moment and reduce the intensity of your physical sensations.

Building self-confidence is another important aspect to address. Engage in activities that boost your self-esteem and allow you to challenge negative beliefs. Consider pursuing hobbies or interests that you excel in, surround yourself with supportive friends, and engage in positive self-talk. Over time, these efforts can help increase your overall confidence and resilience.

Lastly, seeking support from trusted individuals in your life can provide an additional layer of comfort. Share your experiences and feelings with someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member. They may offer perspective, understanding, and advice based on their own experiences.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it may take time to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. With practice and self-compassion, you can gradually overcome these anxiety attacks and regain a sense of confidence in social interactions.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i have been on prozac since maybe september last year before prozac i wa on lexapro and i wa given the highest dose of that and it worked at first and then my anxiety started up really bad again out of nowhere so i wa switched to prozac and honestly i don t feel like i ve noticed a difference especially recently i ve been getting bad anxiety attack that have worsened the past couple month i haven t had attack this bad in month it s honestly the worst ha anyone else experienced this where it feel like nothing is helping your anxiety i just want to be better my mind feel like a mental prison also doe anyone have any tip or trick that have helped calm them during an anxiety attack

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you reached out to share your experience. I understand how frustrating and overwhelming it can be when anxiety feels like a constant obstacle in your way. It's important to remember that everyone's journey with mental health is unique, but I can offer some suggestions and guidance that may help.

Firstly, it's great that you've been proactive in seeking support through therapy. Therapy can provide a safe space for you to explore your thoughts, feelings, and concerns, and work towards finding effective coping mechanisms. Your therapist is there to guide you through this process, so don't hesitate to discuss your experiences and any concerns you may have about your medication.

Regarding your anxiety symptoms, it's not uncommon for individuals to experience fluctuations in their response to medication over time. Several factors could contribute to this, including changes in brain chemistry or the development of tolerance to the medication. Therefore, it's important to maintain open communication with your healthcare provider to discuss potential adjustments or alternatives.

In addition to therapy and medication, there are various strategies you can try to manage your anxiety. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, mindfulness techniques, and grounding exercises have been helpful for many people in reducing anxiety symptoms. You might find it beneficial to experiment with different techniques and incorporate them into your daily routine.

Another aspect worth considering is lifestyle factors that can impact your overall well-being. Regular exercise, adequate sleep, healthy eating habits, and managing stress through activities like journaling, engaging in hobbies, or spending time with loved ones can all contribute positively to your mental health.

Lastly, it's important to remember that progress takes time, and setbacks are a normal part of the journey. Be patient and kind to yourself as you navigate through this process. Celebrate small victories along the way and acknowledge the strength it takes to keep pushing forward.

Remember, I'm here to support you, but it's also crucial to consult with a healthcare professional who can provide personalized advice based on your specific situation. They will have a more comprehensive understanding of your medical history, medication, and can offer guidance tailored to your needs.

Take care and know that you're not alone in this journey.

Lastly, please remember that there is always hope, even when it may seem impossible to see right now. You deserve to be loved and appreciated for who you are.
